title: Challenge 2 Instructions
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE)

title: Challenge 2 Instructions
text:
Challenge Overview
Today’s challenge is to

read in a data set, and describe the data using both words and any supporting information (e.g., tables, etc)
provide summary statistics for different interesting groups within the data, and interpret those statistics

title: Challenge 2 Instructions
text:
Read in the Data
Read in one (or more) of the following data sets, available in the posts/_data folder, using the correct R package and command.

railroad*.csv or StateCounty2012.xlsx ⭐
FAOstat*.csv ⭐⭐⭐
hotel_bookings ⭐⭐⭐⭐




Add any comments or documentation as needed. More challenging data may require additional code chunks and documentation.

title: Challenge 2 Instructions
text:
Describe the data
Using a combination of words and results of R commands, can you provide a high level description of the data? Describe as efficiently as possible where/how the data was (likely) gathered, indicate the cases and variables (both the interpretation and any details you deem useful to the reader to fully understand your chosen data).

title: Challenge 2 Instructions
text:
Provide Grouped Summary Statistics
Conduct some exploratory data analysis, using dplyr commands such as group_by(), select(), filter(), and summarise(). Find the central tendency (mean, median, mode) and dispersion (standard deviation, mix/max/quantile) for different subgroups within the data set.




Explain and Interpret
Be sure to explain why you choose a specific group. Comment on the interpretation of any interesting differences between groups that you uncover. This section can be integrated with the exploratory data analysis, just be sure it is included.

title: Challenge 1
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE)


##Read the data Import data into R as a cvs file. This dataset contains information about the total number of railroad employees per county in the US.


Code
library(readr)
railroad <- read.csv("C:/Users/mmrobinson/Desktop/Github/601_Winter_2022-2023/posts/_data/railroad_2012_clean_county.csv")


Error in file(file, "rt"): cannot open the connection


Code
head(railroad)


Error in head(railroad): object 'railroad' not found


##Get dimension for railroad dataset This dataset has 3 different columns and 2930 rows.


Code
dim(railroad)


Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'railroad' not found


##Get column names of railroad This dataset contains 3 columns named “state”, “county”, and “total_employees.”


Code
colnames(railroad)


Error in is.data.frame(x): object 'railroad' not found


##Select station_county and total_employees columns Focus on the total number of employees per county.


Code
select(railroad, county, total_employees)


Error in select(railroad, county, total_employees): object 'railroad' not found


Code
head(railroad)


Error in head(railroad): object 'railroad' not found


##Arrange data by the total number of employees in descending order Arranging the dataset by the total number of employees in descending order help us determine that Cook, IL has the highest number of employees.


Code
railroad %>%
select(total_employees, state, county) %>%
  arrange(desc(total_employees))


Error in select(., total_employees, state, county): object 'railroad' not found


##Arrange dataset based on the total number of employees per state


Code
railroad%>%
  arrange(desc(total_employees))%>%
  select(total_employees,state, county) %>%
  group_by(state) %>%
    slice(1)%>%
  arrange(desc(total_employees))


Error in arrange(., desc(total_employees)): object 'railroad' not found


##Find the mean of total_employees per state with label


Code
summarise(railroad, mean(total_employees))


Error in summarise(railroad, mean(total_employees)): object 'railroad' not found


##Find basic statistical information on the dataset


Code
summarise(railroad, mean.employees = mean(total_employees), min.employees = min(total_employees), max.employees = max(total_employees), sd.employees = sd(total_employees))


Error in summarise(railroad, mean.employees = mean(total_employees), min.employees = min(total_employees), : object 'railroad' not found


##Find the mean of total_employees per state


Code
railroad %>%
  group_by(state) %>%
  select(state, total_employees) %>%
  summarise_all(mean, na.rm=TRUE)%>%
  arrange(desc(total_employees))


Error in group_by(., state): object 'railroad' not found


##Find the mean of total_employees per county Finding the mean and arranging the dataset by the total number of employees indicated that Delaware has the highest number of employees per station compared to the rest of the states. However, Texas has the most employees per state.


Code
railroad%>%
  group_by(state)%>%
  select(total_employees)%>%
  summarise_all(sum, na.rm = TRUE)%>%
arrange(desc(total_employees))


Error in group_by(., state): object 'railroad' not found


Conclusion - This dataset was likely created by the Railroad system in the United States to document the total number of railroad employees and keep record of its employment. The dataset contains 2930 observations and 3 variables. The county with most employees is in the state of Illinois, however, the state with most employees is in Texas.

read in a dataset, and

title: Challenge 1 Instructions
text:
Read in the Data
Read in one (or more) of the following data sets, using the correct R package and command.

railroad_2012_clean_county.csv ⭐
birds.csv ⭐⭐
FAOstat*.csv ⭐⭐
wild_bird_data.xlsx ⭐⭐⭐
StateCounty2012.xlsx ⭐⭐⭐⭐

Find the _data folder, located inside the posts folder. Then you can read in the data, using either one of the readr standard tidy read commands, or a specialized package such as readxl.



Add any comments or documentation as needed. More challenging data sets may require additional code chunks and documentation.

title: Challenge 1 Instructions
text:
Describe the data
Using a combination of words and results of R commands, can you provide a high level description of the data? Describe as efficiently as possible where/how the data was (likely) gathered, indicate the cases and variables (both the interpretation and any details you deem useful to the reader to fully understand your chosen data).
